__data__.text: Nagaenthran a/l K. Dharmalingam, an Indian Malaysian from Ipoh, was born in 1988 to Panchalai Supermaniam and had three siblings. His father passed away while he was on death row in Singapore. As a child, Nagaenthran was primarily raised by his grandmother and relatives while his mother worked. He finished secondary school at 17 and worked at a factory. Despite his family's opposition, particularly his mother's, Nagaenthran moved to Singapore for employment.

Nagaenthran, born in 1988, moved to Singapore for work and became a security guard. He last visited his family in Ipoh in 2008 during Deepavali. In 2009, at the age of 20, he was apprehended by Central Narcotics Bureau officers at the Woodlands Checkpoint, carrying 42.72g of diamorphine (pure heroin) strapped to his thigh. A friend and traveling companion, Kumarsen, was also arrested but released later. Nagaenthran confessed that he was aware of the drugs and that a Chinese acquaintance, whom he referred to as "King," had concealed them on his person.

After being arrested in 2009 for carrying drugs, Nagaenthran initially admitted to knowingly transporting heroin strapped to his thigh, provided by a Chinese acquaintance called "King," due to financial difficulties. However, he later recanted his confession, claiming King had coerced him. Despite this, Nagaenthran was sentenced to death for drug trafficking, as the amount exceeded the limit for the death penalty, following his conviction in November 2010.

In 2011, Nagaenthran's appeal against his death sentence for drug trafficking was denied, as the judge ruled he bore full responsibility for his actions, despite his claim of duress. A year later, Singapore amended its death penalty laws, imposing life imprisonment and caning as alternatives for drug traffickers who are merely couriers, provided they assist narcotics police in disrupting drug trafficking activities. Nagaenthran's execution was temporarily halted due to this moratorium.

In 2013, Singapore updated its death penalty laws, introducing life imprisonment as an alternative for drug traffickers who serve as couriers and assist narcotics police in disrupting drug trafficking. Additionally, those with diagnosed mental illnesses that significantly impair their mental faculties become ineligible for the death penalty and caning. When the new laws took effect, Nagaenthran, whose execution had been paused, applied for re-sentencing due to claimed clinical intellectual disability and mental illness. However, a psychiatric report found no such issues, and he was ineligible for a certificate of substantive assistance from the Central Narcotics Bureau. Nagaenthran attempted to request mercy in 2015, citing an intellectual disability, low IQ, impaired executive functioning, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Nonetheless, the High Court dismissed his re-sentencing application in 2017.

In 2017 and 2018, the High Court reviewed Nagaenthran's case twice, dismissing his re-sentencing application and a subsequent appeal. In both instances, psychiatric and psychological experts, including a defense-called expert, concurred that Nagaenthran did not have an intellectual disability. The court also noted Nagaenthran's history of inconsistently reporting his educational background and highlighted his ability to manipulate and evade during his offense, as demonstrated by attempting to avoid a search by claiming he worked in security. The Court of Appeal also reviewed the case and ultimately dismissed the appeal.

In 2018, Nagaenthran's appeal to the High Court for a reduced sentence was rejected, and subsequent appeals to the Court of Appeal under new death penalty laws were also dismissed in May 2019. The Court of Appeal found inconsistencies in Nagaenthran's account of his crime, affecting his credibility. The five-judge panel concluded that, despite a potentially low IQ, Nagaenthran's mental responsibility for the offense was not significantly impaired. He demonstrated planning and organizational skills, as well as the ability to live independently. Additionally, Nagaenthran was aware that importing heroin was illegal and took steps to conceal the drugs.

Nagaenthran's appeal for a reduced sentence was denied in 2018 and again in 2019, as the court found inconsistencies in his account of the crime, maintaining his mental responsibility. Despite a lower IQ, he showed planning and independent living skills, and understood that importing heroin was illegal, taking measures to conceal it. He attempted to avoid arrest and showed calculated actions, which were viewed as a "criminal mindset." A clemency petition to Singapore's President was also rejected, finalizing his death sentence.

Clemency is rarely granted in Singapore, with the most recent instance occurring in 1998 when Mathavakannan Kalimuthu, sentenced for murder, was pardoned after 16 years due to good behavior. During Nagaenthran's appeal for clemency, which attracted international attention and requests for mercy, his mother Panchalai Supermaniam and family also pleaded for his life. However, his clemency petition was ultimately denied, resulting in the enforcement of his death sentence.

In 2019, human rights lawyer N Surendran criticized Singapore for imposing a death sentence on a mentally disabled man named Nagaenthran, claiming that his defense's psychiatric evidence was not adequately considered during the trial. However, Singapore's law minister, K Shanmugam, refuted claims of unfair treatment towards Malaysian drug traffickers and stated that the majority of Singaporeans support capital punishment. Shanmugam suggested that it would be beneficial if drug traffickers were apprehended by Malaysian authorities, as they would be subject to Malaysia's laws instead of Singapore's. The minister also emphasized that there should be no special treatment for Malaysian prisoners on death row to maintain the integrity of Singapore's law. Following this, a death warrant and a stay of execution were issued, and the execution date was confirmed.

In 2021, Singapore's law minister, K Shanmugam, stressed no special treatment for Malaysian death row prisoners, upholding the country's legal integrity. A death warrant and stay of execution were issued, with the execution date confirmed for 10 November 2021. This date was conveyed to Nagaenthran's family in Ipoh via a 26 October 2021 letter from Singapore Prison Service. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, an informal execution moratorium had been in place since 2020, allowing Nagaenthran to live for an additional year after his unsuccessful clemency appeal.

The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) will assist Nagaenthran's family with travel arrangements, including quarantine procedures and COVID-19 testing, and allow extended visits with multiple visitors, aiming to balance the need for familial support with COVID-19 precautions during a period of increasing local transmission due to the Delta variant. The SPS mentioned that the last execution before Nagaenthran's was in November 2019, when a Malaysian man was executed despite his country's opposition. This context highlights the Singaporean government's stance on upholding legal integrity and its approach to executions during the pandemic.

The text discusses opposition to the planned execution of Nagaenthran, a Malaysian man, by the Singapore government. Legal representatives and various international and local human rights organizations, such as the World Coalition Against the Death Penalty, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, and the UN Commission on Human Rights, have advocated for clemency. They argue that Nagaenthran is mentally disabled and should not be executed, as he cannot fully comprehend his actions. An online petition with over 102,000 signatures has been submitted to President Halimah Yacob, requesting that Nagaenthran's life be spared. There are plans to bring the case before the International Court of Justice (ICJ), alleging that Singapore is not adhering to international norms against the death penalty. Additionally, there are concerns that executing a mentally unfit offender would violate international human rights and law. The American Psychiatric Association's Social Justice Division has labeled Nagaenthran's case a "flagrant breach" of human rights.

The American Psychiatric Association's Social Justice Division has joined the human rights organizations in denouncing Nagaenthran's case as a violation of human rights. Public figures, including a Singaporean rapper-musician and a British billionaire, along with over 200 family members of other death row convicts, have urged Singapore to show mercy. Protests have occurred in Malaysia, requesting more action from the Malaysian government to prevent the execution. Nagaenthran's family has kept the news of his impending execution from his mother, who reacted negatively when she eventually found out.

Nagaenthran's family was informed of his imminent execution five days after receiving the notice, causing his mother distress. With the assistance of abolitionist advocate Kirsten Han and her group, Malaysian diplomats provided consular support, and funds were raised for Nagaenthran's mother to visit him in prison. During this visit, one of Nagaenthran's brothers noticed that he appeared disoriented.

Nagaenthran's brother observed that he was disoriented during a prison visit, appearing incoherent, smiling randomly, and having trouble making eye contact. He also struggled to recognize people except for his mother. A neighboring death row inmate reported that Nagaenthran had been introverted and silent for over a year. His lawyer, M Ravi, noted that Nagaenthran's behavior was like that of a child, suggesting possible unawareness of his impending execution and potential mental health decline due to his long-term confinement. Amnesty International's Singapore researcher, Rachel Chhoa-Howard, criticized the court's dismissal of Nagaenthran's diminished responsibility claims, calling the use of the death penalty in this case "despicable," particularly in light of concerns about his comprehension of the situation.

Nagaenthran's execution was set to take place just six days after the Hindu festival Deepavali, causing distress for his family who typically celebrate the occasion. A man was arrested for publicly advocating against Nagaenthran's death sentence. The Ministry of Home Affairs released a statement defending their decision to carry out the execution, asserting that Nagaenthran received a fair trial, had legal representation, and did not act under duress or suffer from severe mental impairment. They concluded that there was no need for a case review as all appeal options were already exhausted.

Nagaenthran was found guilty of trafficking a large amount of heroin, enough to supply 510 addicts for a week. His execution was not delayed, despite the proximity to the Deepavali festival. The Singaporean government maintains that strict drug laws, including the death penalty, are crucial for keeping crime rates low and protecting the public from drug-related harm. They emphasized that the penalties for drug trafficking are clearly communicated to potential offenders.

The Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) of Singapore has emphasized the clear communication of penalties for drug trafficking, including the death penalty, to deter potential offenders. Despite this, protests and calls for mercy have arisen in Malaysia, with Malaysian lawyer Mahajoth Singh protesting in front of the Singapore High Commission and lawyer N Surendran arguing against the execution of Nagaenthran, who has a mental disability. Lawyers for Liberty from Malaysia have criticized the Singapore government's response, and the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Ismail Sabri Yaakob, has appealed to Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to review Nagaenthran's case and revoke his death sentence. The Singapore authorities have also scheduled execution dates for other death row inmates.

The Prime Minister of Malaysia, Ismail Sabri Yaakob, who is also a lawyer, has appealed to Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong to review the case of Nagaenthran, a death row inmate, and revoke his death sentence. Ismail expressed respect for Singapore's laws but hoped for a chance for Nagaenthran to review his case. Malaysia's Foreign Minister, Saifuddin Abdullah, also urged his Singaporean counterpart, Vivian Balakrishnan, to allow their authorities some discretion in deciding clemency for Nagaenthran. The European Union, which opposes the death penalty, has added to the pressure on Singapore to pardon Nagaenthran. A last-minute appeal was made on November 8, two days before Nagaenthran's scheduled execution, and was argued at the High Court by M Ravi.

On November 8, two days prior to Nagaenthran's scheduled execution, M Ravi, his lawyer, presented a last-ditch appeal at the High Court. The judge, See Kee Oon, rejected the appeal, asserting that all legal avenues were already exhausted in 2019 and no proof was provided to validate claims of Nagaenthran's deteriorating mental state or his mental age being under 18. M Ravi, lacking medical expertise, had met Nagaenthran only once, six days prior to the appeal, for a mere 26 minutes. COVID-19 restrictions were in place during the hearing.

M Ravi, Nagaenthran's lawyer, who lacks medical expertise, met with him only once for a brief 26 minutes before the appeal. The judge, See Kee Oon, found no evidence to support Nagaenthran's claims of mental decline or being under 18. Ravi's arguments about international law violations were dismissed due to the lack of legal basis for international law to override domestic law. The appeal process was criticized for being rushed, and prison officers' testimonies contradicted claims of Nagaenthran exhibiting mentally ill behavior.

Two prison officers, who have known Nagaenthran for three years, did not observe any abnormal behavior from him. He was able to communicate effectively with officers in multiple languages, request religious counseling, phone calls, and visits from family. The Attorney-General's Chambers attempted to share Nagaenthran's recent psychiatric records with his lawyer, but the lawyer objected. On the day of the appeal, Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia minister appealed to Singapore to reconsider Nagaenthran's case and save his life.

UN human rights experts joined Malaysia's Communications and Multimedia minister in urging Singapore to spare Nagaenthran's life. However, his execution was postponed due to his positive COVID-19 diagnosis, which was discovered just 12 minutes after his arrival at the Court of Appeal for his hearing. The appeal was delayed to give Nagaenthran time to recover. He had tested negative in an initial ART test but later tested positive in a PCR test. The court, packed with local and international media and activists, heard his appeal from three judges. Neither Nagaenthran nor the officials were aware of his infection before the court appearance.

The text reveals that Nagaenthran, whose execution was postponed due to a COVID-19 diagnosis, had opted not to get vaccinated against the virus. This, despite a high vaccination rate among prison staff and inmates. Subsequently, several officers and some of Nagaenthran's fellow prisoners tested positive, leading to lockdowns and isolations. Regular testing for COVID-19 is now being implemented in the prison. The situation has highlighted the debate around the death penalty in Singapore and Malaysia.

The text continues to discuss the debate on the death penalty in Malaysia, sparked by Nagaenthran's case. Many human rights groups advocate for the abolition of capital punishment, but a significant number of Malaysians think it should stay for severe crimes like murder and specific corruption offenses, excluding drug trafficking. Support for the death penalty remains strong in Malaysia, despite a decrease in new death sentences. Legal experts and enforcement officials, including lawyers and police officers, suggest that judges should have discretionary powers to impose life imprisonment in certain capital cases, taking into account mitigating circumstances. However, they generally believe that the death penalty remains applicable for drug trafficking, murder, and other offenses due to the high rate of drug-related crimes in Malaysia. The Singaporean government's response to the situation involves implementing regular COVID-19 testing in the prison.

Datuk Seri Nazri Abdul Aziz, during the Budget 2022 debate, suggested that Malaysia reconsider its death penalty laws for drug traffickers, as executing drug offenders while advocating for mercy for Malaysian citizens abroad is inconsistent. This statement comes as the UN urges Singapore to pardon Nagaenthran, a drug trafficker. However, Singapore's UN representative and Ambassador Umej Bhatia argued that Nagaenthran does not have a mild intellectual disability, as determined by their courts and supported by his personal psychiatrist, justifying their stance on his execution.

In response to the UN's claims, Singapore asserts its sovereign right to determine the use of the death penalty and the definition of capital offenses, emphasizing the lack of international consensus on this matter and the severity of crimes. Singapore also defends the independence of its prosecution and the fairness of the legal process, highlighting Nagaenthran's opportunity to appeal the court's decision regarding the prosecution's actions.

Singapore's COVID-19 travel restrictions, applied equally to all travelers from Malaysia, were not intended to discriminate against Nagaenthran's family and were implemented for pandemic control. The Singaporean government maintains that Nagaenthran is receiving a fair trial and is not intellectually disabled, as confirmed by courts and psychiatric assessments. However, N. Surendran and Lawyers for Liberty from Malaysia argue that the courts have not provided Nagaenthran with a full and fair trial, disregarding his intellectual and mental impairments during the proceedings.

Human Rights Watch's senior disability rights expert, Emina Ćerimović, criticized Nagaenthran's case, finding the actions of the Singaporean authorities towards a man with intellectual disabilities inhumane. She argued that seeking the death penalty for someone with such impairments, who was convicted for importing a small amount of drugs, is disproportionate and cruel, deserving global condemnation. Malaysian legal organizations, including the Malaysian Bar, Advocates Association of Sarawak, and Sabah Law Society, have appealed to the Singapore government for clemency. They urged Singapore to evaluate Nagaenthran's mental competence due to concerns over the potential psychological impact of his 11-year death row period, all while expressing respect for Singapore's legal system.

Nagaenthran's family and lawyer, M Ravi, plan to take legal action against Singapore's attorney general, Lucien Wong, for negligence and disregard of human life. Ravi refuses to retract his criticism of the judicial system, despite Wong's warning of contempt of court. Meanwhile, Yang di-Pertuan Agong from Malaysia has appealed to Singapore's President for clemency. The final appeal hearing, initially set for November 30, has been rescheduled to January 2022. Activist Angelia Pranthaman, whose brother was on death row, shared this update.

Activist Angelia Pranthaman announced the postponement of Nagaenthran's final appeal hearing to January 2022, though his lawyer, M Ravi, who requested the adjournment due to his suspension from legal duties, did not receive a specific date. Pranthaman, whose brother was on death row, urged for clemency for both men. President Halimah Yacob rejected the Malaysian king's plea for Nagaenthran's life, asserting that he was receiving a fair trial. The new court date for Nagaenthran's appeal is January 24, 2022.

In January 2022, Nagaenthran's final appeal was heard by a panel of five judges, including Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon and Judges of Appeal Andrew Phang, Judith Prakash, Belinda Ang, and Senior Judge Chao Hick Tin. Nagaenthran's lawyer, M Ravi, was replaced by Violet Netto. Prior to the appeal, there was a push from the international community to spare Nagaenthran from execution. Netto requested an adjournment, which was granted, and the appeal was eventually heard on March 1, 2022. During the hearing, Netto argued for a psychiatric assessment of Nagaenthran and attempted to submit reports from two foreign psychologists as evidence. However, the judges deemed this last-minute submission as an abuse of the court process.

In Nagaenthran's final appeal hearing in January 2022, his new lawyer, Violet Netto, tried to submit last-minute evidence from two foreign psychologists and requested a psychiatric assessment. However, the judges, including Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon, viewed this as an abuse of the court process. The prosecution criticized Netto for attempting to suppress Changi Prison's medical records. The judgement was reserved, and Nagaenthran remained in prison while awaiting the verdict. Four weeks later, the Court of Appeal dismissed the appeal, citing the use of inadmissible evidence and unsubstantiated claims about Nagaenthran's mental age. The judges, including Menon, criticized Netto and Nagaenthran's previous lawyer, M. Ravi, for abusing the court process.

The court rejected new evidence from foreign psychologists as they did not directly assess Nagaenthran, and instead relied on the initial court's findings that he had borderline intellectual functioning but not mild intellectual disability. The court criticized Nagaenthran's lawyers for objecting to the use of his 2021 medical reports, which could have supported his claim of a medical condition. The court suggested that Nagaenthran attempted to prevent the use of this evidence to avoid it undermining his case. The court viewed the appeal as a baseless attempt to avoid the death penalty and defer his execution.

The court turned down additional evidence and criticized Nagaenthran's lawyers for making repeated, unfounded appeals aimed at delaying the execution. The judge, Menon, condemned these actions as an abuse of the court process and upheld the capital punishment. Upon dismissal of the appeal, Nagaenthran was scheduled for execution, causing distress to his family. Subsequently, various civil groups have sought clemency for Nagaenthran, asking Singapore to show mercy.

After the court rejected Nagaenthran's final appeal and scheduled his execution, various civil groups, including Reprieve, Lawyers for Liberty, and the Global Commission on Drug Policy, advocated for clemency. These groups urged Singapore's President Halimah Yacob to grant mercy, asserted that the government violated international law, and called on the Malaysian government to take the case to the International Court of Justice. They argue that imposing the death penalty on individuals with intellectual disabilities, like Nagaenthran, is inappropriate, even for drug-related offenses.

The Global Commission on Drug Policy argues against using the death penalty, even for drug-related crimes, using Nagaenthran's case as an example. A protest took place at Hong Lim Park, opposing the government's application of the death penalty in Nagaenthran's situation. Additionally, the ASEAN Intergovernmental Commission on Human Rights was asked to intervene in Nagaenthran's case and advocate for the abolition of the death penalty in ASEAN countries. There is a divided public opinion on whether Nagaenthran should be spared from execution or face it for his crime.

In a recent survey, over 80% of Singaporeans supported keeping the death penalty due to its deterrent effect on crime. After Nagaenthran's unsuccessful appeal, his lawyer, M Ravi, announced no more appeals would be made, and the execution could occur imminently. This concern was heightened when another inmate, Abdul Kahar bin Othman, was executed, marking the first hanging during the COVID-19 pandemic. On April 16, 2022, Kokila Annamalai reported that Nagaenthran's second clemency appeal, submitted by his family and supporters, was denied by Singapore's President on March 31, 2022.

After Nagaenthran's second clemency appeal was denied, his execution is now scheduled for April 27, 2022. His lawyer, M Ravi, and Kokila Annamalai have criticized Singapore's decision and the lack of mercy shown towards Nagaenthran. Annamalai, who has witnessed Nagaenthran's loving relationship with his family, expressed sadness about his impending execution. The Malaysian government is being urged to intervene by taking the case to the International Court of Justice. Nagaenthran's mother will be allowed extended daily visits until the day before his execution.

Following the confirmation of Nagaenthran's execution date, there have been calls for the Malaysian government to intervene by taking the case to the International Court of Justice. Nagaenthran's mother, Panchalai Supermaniam, made a public plea for mercy on her son's behalf, while Amnesty International filed a petition with over 8,000 signatures seeking clemency. Activist Kokila Annamalai planned a candlelight vigil, and Nagaenthran's family prepared to visit him in prison. Additionally, British celebrities Richard Branson and Stephen Fry renewed their appeals for Nagaenthran's sentence to be commuted.

After Nagaenthran's execution date was set, Richard Branson and Stephen Fry renewed their appeals on social media for commuting Nagaenthran's sentence. Branson criticized the death penalty in Singapore and suggested transferring Nagaenthran to a Malaysian prison. Human rights groups and activists organized a candlelight vigil, which was attended by several public figures. The protests intensified due to the finalization of Datchinamurthy Kataiah's execution date, which was set two days after Nagaenthran's.

A candlelight vigil was conducted as planned, attracting public figures such as Subhas Nair, Paul Tambyah, and Alfian Sa'at, as well as Singaporeans seeking understanding of the death penalty. Nagaenthran's cousin, Thenmoli Sunniah, spoke on behalf of the family, expressing their continued hope for a legal resolution despite foreigner-participation laws. Datchinamurthy's family joined the vigil in solidarity, opposing both executions.

The families of Nagaenthran and Datchinamurthy, two friends on death row, attended the candlelight vigil together in a show of solidarity and opposition to their executions. Sebaran Kasih, an NGO, urged political and business leaders to intervene in Nagaenthran's case, comparing it to the 2010 cases of Cheong Chun Yin and Pang Siew Fum. Both Cheong and Pang were initially sentenced to death for drug trafficking but had their sentences reduced to life imprisonment due to mitigating circumstances. The NGO questioned why Nagaenthran could not also be considered for life imprisonment given the similarities in their cases.

Activists, lawyers from Malaysian Indian Congress, and the UN Human Rights Office protested Nagaenthran's execution, leading to the questioning of three lawyers by Royal Malaysia Police. The UN expressed concern over Singapore's increasing use of death penalty for drug offenses and urged reconsideration of drug laws. Nagaenthran's mother sued Singapore's Chief Justice as a last resort to save her son.

Nagaenthran's mother, Panchalai, with the aid of activists, family, and friends, sued Singapore's Chief Justice, Menon, alleging bias as he was the previous attorney general who prosecuted and secured Nagaenthran's conviction. However, she had to represent herself in the lawsuit hearing, set for the day before the execution, as no lawyer in Singapore dared to represent her due to potential court reprisals. On April 26, 2022, the Court of Appeal, composed of Belinda Ang, Andrew Phang, and Judith Prakash, dismissed the lawsuit, deeming it meritless.

The Court of Appeal, comprised of Belinda Ang, Andrew Phang, and Judith Prakash, unanimously decided that Panchalai's lawsuit was baseless and devoid of merit. Justice Phang expressed that courts cannot be used for prolonging matters without proper grounds, and Nagaenthran's mother was criticized for abusing the court process by filing a meritless lawsuit. The Deputy Public Prosecutor, Wong Woon Kwong, highlighted that Chief Justice Menon had no involvement in Nagaenthran's prosecution decisions.

The Court of Appeal, after dismissing Panchalai's lawsuit as groundless, allowed Nagaenthran to spend time with his family in the court building and hold their hands before his execution. The Deputy Public Prosecutor had requested the court to reveal those involved in the baseless lawsuit to prevent further attacks on the justice system. Following the lawsuit's dismissal, Nagaenthran bid farewell to his family and was taken back to prison, while activists in Malaysia held a vigil upon hearing the news of his execution.

After the Court of Appeal dismissed Panchalai's lawsuit as baseless, Nagaenthran was allowed to spend time with his family before his execution. However, activists in Malaysia held a vigil, attended by 50 people, where two Malaysian lawyers were investigated by the police for participating. Lawyers for Liberty accused Singaporean authorities of harassing Nagaenthran's mother to reveal those who helped file the lawsuit. Nagaenthran was executed on 27 April 2022, being the second prisoner executed after the COVID-19 pandemic moratorium. He was the fifth Malaysian drug trafficker executed in Singapore since 2016. Nagaenthran's family, including his 22-year-old brother, planned to collect his body for funeral preparations in Ipoh.

Nagaenthran's sister, Sharmila, expressed grief and disappointment over his execution, which took place on 27 April 2022. Before the body was transported to Malaysia, a wake was held in Singapore with around a hundred attendees. The funeral, held in Ipoh, was attended by over 200 family members and friends, but politicians were not allowed due to Sharmila's belief that they were seeking publicity without supporting Nagaenthran during his imprisonment. In 2022, Singapore executed eleven individuals for drug trafficking, Nagaenthran being one of them.

Following Nagaenthran's execution, criticism and mourning ensued. Maya Foa, Reprieve's director, deemed it a miscarriage of justice, while M Ravi expressed condolences and vowed to keep advocating against the death penalty in Singapore. Activist Kirsten Han shared a personal photo of Nagaenthran, and the Malaysian government received requests to abolish capital punishment, with PKR leader Jimmy Puah Wee Tse considering it an ineffective deterrent for crime.

The Malaysian government's Wisma Putra expressed condolences to Nagaenthran's family and provided them support, while British billionaire Richard Branson, who previously advocated for clemency, shared his disappointment in Singapore's "ruthless death machinery" and lack of mercy. The Anti-Death Penalty Asia Network (ADPAN) criticized Nagaenthran's execution as a breach of international law.

The Anti-Death Penalty Asia Network (ADPAN) strongly criticized Nagaenthran's execution as a violation of international law, while Amnesty International's Erwin van der Borght called it a "disgraceful" act carried out by Singapore's government. Australian human rights lawyer Julian McMahon, who has represented other drug traffickers facing the death penalty, also spoke out against Nagaenthran's execution and the use of capital punishment.

The lawyers, McMahon and Bailes, condemned Nagaenthran's execution, viewing it as a failure in preventing drug trafficking since it targets low-level offenders rather than the kingpins. They argue that capital punishment is not an effective deterrent, as demonstrated by the experience of numerous countries. Bailes emphasized the irreversibility of the death penalty, even when mistakes occur in the legal process. The case also highlighted previous executions of Australians for drug offenses in Southeast Asian countries.

The Nagaenthran case drew attention to past executions of Australians for drug offenses in Southeast Asian nations, such as Barlow and Chambers in Malaysia, Van Tuong Nguyen in Singapore, and Chan and Sukumaran of Bali Nine in Indonesia. It also highlighted the plight of nine Malaysians on Singapore's death row, including Datchinamurthy Kataiah and Pannir Selvam Pranthaman, who faced execution despite being labeled as couriers or having disabilities. Activists opposing capital punishment expressed concern about the potential execution of these individuals. The United Nations criticized Singapore for executing Nagaenthran and Abdul Kahar Othman, calling for a moratorium on the death penalty and urging against executing Datchinamurthy Kataiah. The government responded to these criticisms.

On the day of Nagaenthran's execution, the Attorney-General's Chambers (AGC) released a statement rejecting allegations and rumors related to the case, particularly those implying bias from Chief Justice Sundaresh Menon. The AGC noted that the lawsuit against Menon was the seventh legal application made on Nagaenthran's behalf and viewed it as an abuse of the court process to unnecessarily delay the enforcement of Nagaenthran's sentence. The AGC had previously informed Nagaenthran's counsel about Menon's role as Attorney General during Nagaenthran's prosecution, and Nagaenthran, following his lawyer's advice, did not object to Menon presiding over the lawsuit.

The AGC accused Nagaenthran's mother and her allies of making a legal application containing false information, as they claimed the involvement of Nagaenthran's mother was misrepresented, and the necessary details were withheld. The AGC saw this as an attempt to unfairly delay the execution and deemed it contempt of court. After Nagaenthran's execution, the AGC and CNB released statements defending their decision, addressing international criticism of Singapore's choice to carry out the death penalty.

In statements, the AGC and CNB reaffirmed their stance on Nagaenthran's case. The AGC emphasized that Nagaenthran received a fair trial and had utilized all possible legal appeals over a decade. Meanwhile, the CNB clarified that Nagaenthran's actions were deliberate and that he was aware of his actions at the time of the crime, as concluded by the judges. The CNB also addressed misinformation regarding Nagaenthran's mental state, asserting that he was not intellectually disabled during the offense.

The government's stance on Nagaenthran's case received backing from various parties. Before the execution, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan informed their Malaysian counterparts that Nagaenthran had undergone complete legal proceedings. Malaysia's foreign minister, Saifuddin Abdullah, acknowledged the execution and stated that it would not impact diplomatic relations between the two countries, as they respect Singapore's sovereignty in managing its judicial system and laws. Additionally, Ambassador Umej Bhatia defended the government's decisions and use of the death penalty for drug-related crimes, emphasizing that all legal proceedings in Singapore are fair and impartial.

Ambassador Umej Bhatia affirmed that criminal proceedings in Singapore are conducted fairly and impartially, with the death penalty being applied if guilt is proven according to the law. He highlighted Singapore's reputation for a fair and impartial justice system and refuted claims of racial bias in the application of the death penalty, emphasizing equal treatment under the law regardless of race or nationality. Bhatia also argued against the need for a moratorium on the death penalty, stating that there is no international consensus against its use when imposed according to due process, and no clear definition of "most serious crimes" under international law.

Ambassador Bhatia and Minister of State Faishal emphasized the fairness and impartiality of Singapore's justice system, rejecting claims of racial bias and the need for a moratorium on the death penalty. They highlighted every nation's sovereign right to establish its criminal justice system according to its circumstances and international law obligations. In response to Nagaenthran's case and alleged court process abuses, Faishal mentioned upcoming legislative changes to penalize such abuses. Both officials underlined the importance of respecting the law and highlighted the destructive consequences of drug abuse, using recent incidents as examples.

During a BBC HARDtalk interview in June 2022, Shanmugam defended Singapore's continuation of the war on drugs and the use of the death penalty, emphasizing its role in protecting citizens and reducing drug-related deaths. He referred to a 2021 WHO report that revealed 500,000 fatalities linked to drug abuse in a single year, and highlighted the decrease in drug-related arrests from 6,000 to 3,000 annually, attributing this decline to Singapore's strict drug trafficking laws.

In the BBC HARDtalk interview, Shanmugam justified Singapore's execution of drug traffickers, including Nagaenthran, by emphasizing the role of capital punishment in protecting citizens and reducing drug-related fatalities. He mentioned a WHO report of 500,000 drug-abuse deaths and a decrease in drug-related arrests. Shanmugam argued that Nagaenthran was not intellectually disabled and had knowingly trafficked drugs. He also cited similar cases of executed Americans to support his argument. He urged Sackur to consider the broader issue of Southeast Asia's severe drug problem, stating that focusing on one execution is misguided. The public on social media largely supported Shanmugam's stance on the death penalty.

In the BBC interview, Shanmugam's defense of Singapore's use of capital punishment for drug traffickers, including Nagaenthran, received public support. However, opposition parties, Reform Party, People's Power Party, and Red Dot United, raised concerns about lawyers being discouraged from representing death row inmates due to a perceived climate of fear. They highlighted the importance of legal representation under Singapore law and urged the government to address these allegations to protect the country's reputation. Separately, Chief Justice Menon noted an increasing trend of frivolous legal challenges against the death penalty, specifically citing Nagaenthran's case as an example of process abuse.

The Chief Justice of Singapore, Menon, urged lawyers to refrain from frivolous legal challenges against the death penalty, mentioning Nagaenthran's case as an example of misuse of the process. In line with this, Violet Netto, Nagaenthran's lawyer in his second-to-last appeal, was arrested and investigated for practicing without a valid certificate, which is required annually. This occurred in Nagaenthran's case and in the final appeals of two other death row inmates, Pausi Jefridin and Roslan Bakar.

The text discusses legal consequences faced by lawyers involved in challenging the death penalty, using Nagaenthran's case as an example. Violet Netto, one of Nagaenthran's lawyers, was investigated and potentially faced penalties for practicing without a valid annual certificate, which could result in up to six months' jail, a fine, or both if convicted. M Ravi, another lawyer who previously represented Nagaenthran, faced multiple professional disciplinary inquiries that could lead to fines, suspensions, or disbarment. Additionally, Ravi faced contempt proceedings, police investigations, and a travel ban restricting him from going to Malaysia, all related to his handling of Nagaenthran's case.

Critics, including Malaysian lawyers and human rights groups, have accused Singapore of harassing lawyers involved in Nagaenthran's case, such as M Ravi and Violet Netto, by imposing penalties like travel restrictions, disciplinary actions, and fines. These lawyers faced investigations and contempt proceedings that led to a court order on May 25, 2022, requiring them to pay over S$20,000 in costs to the Attorney-General's Chambers due to unsubstantiated lawsuits in Nagaenthran's case. Ravi was assigned 75% of the total cost, while Netto was assigned 25%. Activists have criticized Singapore for punishing the lawyers for carrying out their professional duties for their client.

After being fined for their work on Nagaenthran's case, lawyers M Ravi and Violet Netto received public funding support due to the financial penalties they incurred. Activists, including Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe, were investigated by police for organizing unauthorized assemblies against the death penalty and for possessing anti-death penalty shirts and other items. This all occurred following the executions of Abdul Kahar Othman and Nagaenthran. Additionally, the Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill was passed. Critics argue that these actions punish lawyers and activists for performing their professional duties and expressing their opinions.

Following the executions of Abdul Kahar Othman and Nagaenthran, lawyers M Ravi and Violet Netto received public funding support due to fines, while activists Kirsten Han and Rocky Howe were investigated for organizing unauthorized assemblies and possessing anti-death penalty items. The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill was passed, allowing only the Court of Appeal to grant a stay of execution and hear post-appeal applications. If a prisoner is found to have abused court processes, they will be barred from making a post-appeal application unless new evidence emerges. Activists Han and Howe were asked to provide their anti-death penalty shirts, handphones, and other items as evidence for police investigations. The new law aims to prevent court process abuses in capital punishment cases that have exhausted appeals and clemency processes.

The Post-Appeal Applications in Capital Cases Bill was enacted on November 29, 2022, with general support, except for criticism from Human Rights Watch. This law empowers the Court of Appeal to be the sole authority to consider post-appeal applications and stay executions in capital cases. It also restricts prisoners from making further applications unless new evidence arises, especially if they are deemed to have misused court processes. The law's intention is to prevent abuse of court processes in capital punishment cases that have already gone through appeals and clemency processes. Critics argue that this law limits inmates' opportunities to contest their executions and access to final avenues for justice.
